metadata.name: Intangible #68
metadata.description:
Let me take you places. Those are not in your town, not even on your planet. They’re placed somewhere between reality and subconsciousness.
Enormous, peculiar structures emerge upon you, refusing to be ignored. They are your unfulfilled cravings or ever-lurking demons. They were always there, under your skin, intangible, now they’ve materialized.
You may not like them, they may seem too vast, too scary to tame. But ultimately, you have to face them, unless you enjoy living in their shadow. 

___
Inspirations

I’ve never truly realized that, but ever since I remember, the sight of gigantic objects or creatures evoked strong emotions within me.
It probably started with playing Shadow of Colossus (a video game) as a kid and seeing The Cathedral (short movie by Tomasz Bagiński). Years later, reading Solaris (by Stanisław Lem) aroused the same feeling (among others) of being mesmerized by the vastness. More recently, movies like Denis Villeneuve’s Arrival (which also nudged my attraction to mystery) and Dune - have charmed me.

Earlier this year I have stumbled across Dawid Planeta (artist and yoga teacher) and began contemplating his visions of mini people in the jungle inhabited by giant animals. These works in particular, plus Hollow - generative series by Jacek Markusiewicz - were probably my final inspirations to make Intangible look the way it does.

Settling semi-random generative structures in some kind of reality, gave them a meaning - they may symbolize things much bigger than you - the ones you try to escape from or those you’ve been longing to experience for years. I have mine, don’t you?

___
Controls in live mode


Keyboard
[ space ] - toggle light animation
[ S ] - save image with current size (default is 120% of browser window’s height; you may change browser’s scale or check URL size param)
[ F ] - fullscreen 
[ up / down ] - light intensity
[ left / right ] - base light position
[ 1..5 ] - aspect ratio: 10:16 („zero” ratio), 1:1.4142 (vertical A4), 1:1, 1.4142 (horizontal A4), 16:10
[ B ] - toggle border
[ Z ] - toggle canvas „raw” mode - no shadow / margin (auto applied in fullscreen mode)
[ N ] - toggle „that thing you may not want on print”


URL params
You may add any number of parameters to the URL to start it with particular settings. 
[ animate ] (1/0) - toggle light animation
[ size] (number) - number of px for longer edge, i.e. 4000
[ ratio ] (number or ratio with format: 10/16, 10:16, 10_16) - aspect ratio
[ light ] (number 40..120, some palettes have slightly different limits for good results) - light intensity
[ lightShift] (number -100..100) - base light position
[ border ] (1/0) - toggle border
[ hddcy ] (0/1)

Example: [ &size=4000&border=1&light=100&animate=1 ] 


Mobile
[hold 2 fingers for 2s] - save
[double tap] - fullscreen


___
Note:
I encourage you to do some light adjustments before you save an image for print. I’m pretty sure you can do better than fxrand().


___
Special thanks to my brother Krzycho, for lots of advices / heathy criticism and to Olga, for never-ending excitement and „dorady”.

___
Developed in Javascript, using p5.js (2D Canvas) and chroma.js.
License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

© April-July 2022, MadeUpLifeforms (mulf)

metadata.name: Polar Grid #642
metadata.description:
Polar Grid is part of the fxhash live minting experience at Proof of People, London 2022.

This is a study of color, motion, and composition, and an homage to cinema as an artform. Colorful shapes overlap and pulse in a ever repeating dance. An abstracted movie experience. Each color palette in the series (except one) is inspired by a different film director (if you want a real challenge, see how many you can guess without looking at the feature names).

The palettes were extracted from movie stills or movie posters and fine tuned by hand. As often, I have to thank independent tool makers for their indirect help. My gratitude goes to David Aerne for FarbVélo and Fabrizio Bianchi for Coolors.

The code for Polar Grid is based on early iterations of what ultimately became my carat series. Both projects come from the same fascination for color as a system, even though I used a different approach here. You could call this a carat prequel.

The animation is done using a technique called polar noise. This makes it so the motion of all elements ends up repeating in the same amount of time. This is useful for generating motion that loops perfectly while still appearing organic. In this particular case, the animation repeats every π × 100 seconds.

A challenge in building any generative system is to find the right balance between coherence and variety. I designed the system with the large edition size in mind. During development I generated hundreds of iterations and tweaked my code to make sure that every iteration is truly unique and fits the overall aesthetic of the collection.

I truly hope you will enjoy your own little abstract movie.

— Raphaël de Courville


Released: July 6th 2022

Medium: p5.js, html canvas, css

Reference: sk220621


**About the artist**

Raphaël de Courville is a generative artist, streamer, and educator. His artistic work is an exploration of generative systems, patterns, interactivity, and time. Born in Paris, he lives and works in Berlin.


**Instructions**

- Click/Tap or press SPACEBAR to play and pause the animation

In Fullscreen mode (desktop only):
- Press UP or DOWN arrows to adjust image quality (Note: this can affect performance)
- Press F to hide/show the browser UI

metadata.name: PNTL #17
metadata.description:
PNTL is a generative PFP art with no utilities, no roadmaps, no twitter or even discord. 
the benefit of collecting this PFP is that you will have the cutest PFP in Tezos blockchain.

metadata.name: Otros Ojos #96
metadata.description:
This piece started with the idea of rough-drawing a source of light in a way that looked organic, not purely geometric and/or mesmerizing.
But then, people: Alien skies, tunnels, the eye of god, an exercise on color, shape and texture…
In art, as in life, the biggest variations come from the viewer.
And now that thought is part of how the algorithm sets its traits. You'll see.

So thank you to the opinionated. This work is yours too!

KEYS
- "s" : save image at current resolution
- "h" : save image in hi-res (2875x4000px good for 4K display and A4 print)

metadata.name: Breakers #221
metadata.description:
Companion project to Neural Collapse (#15780), for the collectors of my previous efforts.
A study on the repetition and stacking of a simple dynamic structure, this time inside a cylinder.

Everything procedurally generated at runtime.

Interactivity : 
- You can click on each individual breaker to open or close them. The problem is it will toggle others.
- Press and hold the mouse button to slightly move the viewpoint. The previous interaction not being disabled while doing that, you get some switching all over the place as a bonus bug/feature.

- Press "a" to increase quality of the antialiasing (3 levels), at the cost of performances. If you don't like jaggies and your machine can take it.
- Export a PNG capture at various resolutions by pressing the number keys 1 to 9 (top row or numpad, and only in live mode, after pressing "open"). Resolutions ranges from 720 to 7680 pixels. I recommend starting with "4".

GPU recommended. Best performances on Chrome in general.

metadata.name: Orbs #133
metadata.description:
Serene orbs,
Playfully dynamic,
Soft visceral airy bodies,
Bold, colorful, at once moving, still, tiny, colossal,
Intimate organized chaos, both calm and ethereally energetic

(Created with p5.js and a WEBGL shader.)

metadata.name: Gradient Ascent #3
metadata.description:
Generates a lo-fi sci-fi landscape and applies effects to the result. Most are 2:3 portrait aspect ratio with a smaller chance for landscape or square.

Several cool bonus features are included. Click to draw the image without post processing which can also be downloaded. The unique effect for each iteration can be applied to any image, just drag and drop! There are also URL commands included for advanced users.

Controls

Click = Toggle Processing
Drag & Drop = Process an Image
1 = Toggle processing
2 = Increase resolution
3 = Save as a png

URL Commands

width and height = Change the output size
hd = Set to 1 to show HD by default

Programmed in Vanilla JavaScript by KilledByAPixel
Code and Outputs are Copyright (C) 2022 Frank Force
Artwork is released under CC BY-NC 4.0

metadata.name: L. T. T. Remainder term #16
metadata.description:
L. T. T. Remainder term

- Using WEBGL1.0
- Textures/Images: None
- 3D Model data: None
- Library: None
- Vertex Shader: 1
- Fragment Shader: 1


Note:
Keyboard m key: Opens the menu. You can save the resolution and the image.
Keyboard f key: fit the screen.
The minimum resolution is 1600px x1600px, but no upper limit is set. The limit is determined by your machine and browser.

GPU is required because of WebGL.

metadata.name: Quad-Overlaps #58
metadata.description:
A simple study in color and shape overlap by Nate Donato. This collection features a large number of generative quadrilaterals and a unique painting algorithm of tinting select overlapping sections, combining to produce a wide range of unique outputs that toe a visually pleasing line between order and chaos. Inspired by early computer art pioneers such as Georg Nees and Vera Molnár, the piece builds on their work exposing how even simplistic algorithms can lead to exciting and unexpected results.


13 possible color schemes (some with random tint variations). Multiple draw modes.
Chances for extra jumbled shapes or other rare variants.


Keyboard controls, make sure to click the window into focus to use:

Press [1] to view at native size.
Press [2] to view at large size.
Press [0] to return to default view.

Press [s] to download and save as PNG.

metadata.name: Noren #25
metadata.description:
06/22 Okuizumi
Write in p5js
